hedline.hl1: From Rails to Trails, With Miles and Miles to Explore

abstract.p: Rails to Trails Conservancy Web site covers the more than 11,000 miles of abandoned railroad corridors that have been converted into public trails and greenways for activities like walking, bicycling, horseback riding and cross-country skiing; photo (M)

block.p: More than 11,000 miles of abandoned railroad corridors have been converted into public trails and greenways for activities like walking, bicycling, horseback riding and cross-country skiing.

The trails, which pass through urban, surburban and rural areas for from two-tenths of a mile to more than 200 miles, can be found on an online directory started by the Rails to Trails Conservancy (www.traillink.com).

There are also links, like one for the Virginia Creeper Trail (shown here), which runs along the former right-of-way of the Virginia-Carolina Railroad from Abingdon, Va., to North Carolina.
